Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a New Surgical Drape on Cutaneous Heat Loss

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to be covered with either the new drape or two conventional drapes

Participants.evidence: 8 healthy adult volunteers in a controlled laboratory setting

Intervention.evidence: covered with either the new drape or two conventional drapes

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether a new moisture-impervious surgical drape reduces evaporative heat loss more effectively than conventional drapes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Cutaneous heat loss and skin-surface temperatures were measured using 15 area-weighted thermal flux transducers.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Analysed.evidence: All 8 participants completed the study, and data were analysed per-protocol.

Result_Outcome.evidence: baseline heat loss was 82±14 watts (W), decreasing by 30% with any drape (P<0.001).
